awd_abstract_narration:
Collaborative Research:  Retention of Anisotropic Colloids in Porous Media: A Modeling and Experimental Investigation at Multiple Scales

Abstract

Groundwater is one of the most important components of the hydrologic cycle, serving as the source of about 33 percent of public water supply and providing drinking water to more than 90 percent of the rural population in the United States. Biological (bacteria) and non-biological (soil particles) natural colloids are ubiquitous in groundwater. The transport of pathogens (biological colloids) is relevant to producing safe drinking water, and the transport of heavy metals as facilitated by colloids (non-biological colloids) in groundwater has been widely recognized as a serious public concern. Almost all natural colloids are anisotropic in nature, being non-spherical in shape and possessing varied degrees of heterogeneity in surface charge. This project addresses the limitations of our current understanding of transport and fate of colloidal particles in porous media that stem from approximations of spherical shape and uniform surface charge used in previous studies. An improved understanding of colloid transport and retention in the environment will provide critical knowledge needed for producing safe drinking water and protecting sustainable water resources, essential steps for human health and development. Results from this work will be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate curriculums. Interactive demonstrations on environmental aspects of colloids and nanomaterials will engage middle- and high-school students during a two-week summer camp that encourages interest in STEM disciplines among women and under-represented minorities.

This project is a combined experimental and modeling study that integrates considerations of shape anisotropy and surface-charge heterogeneity.  The research uses a multi-scale approach to investigate the retention of anisotropic colloids onto flat surfaces, at grain-to-grain contacts, and in complex porous media. Systematic experiments using laboratory-prepared rod-shaped colloidal particles with various aspect ratios and surface-charge heterogeneity will be analyzed in novel ways.  Applications of cutting-edge methodologies in microelectronics, high-resolution mass sensing, optical microscopy, and laser-scanning cytometry will enable observations of colloid attachment rates on the surfaces and pore throats of the mineral grains comprising porous media and reveal phenomena appropriate to scaling up observations to aquifers. In parallel, a numerical simulation model that is capable of tracking both the movement and orientation of anisotropic colloids within porous media will be developed. The results of this project provide predictive quantification on how non-spherical shape and surface-charge heterogeneity impact transport and retention of anisotropic colloids.

por.por_cntn:
Natural or engineered colloidal particles exist in diverse sizes, shapes (often non-spherical), and with various degrees of surface heterogeneities (e.g., charge, roughness). The widely-used "homogeneous sphere" assumption for these particles fails to describe many colloidal transport and retention phenomena observed from experiments. Non-spherical particle shape is hypothesized to alter colloid-fluid-collector interactions, which cause the transport and retention of anisotropic colloids significantly different from those of "homogeneous sphere" representations.

This award was part of a collaborative research on anisotropic colloid transport in porous media at multiple scales, primarily focusing on numerical modeling to test the above hypothesis under environmentally relevant conditions. A particle trajectory model at pore scale has been successfully developed to simulate the three-dimensional translation and rotation of ellipsoidal colloids in shear flow under the influences of hydrodynamic fluid flow, external forces (e.g., gravity, colloidal/non-colloidal interactions) and Brownian motions. In shear flow, rod-shaped colloids (prolate ellipsoids) undergo tumbling motions, which have been successfully confirmed from simulations and experiments; the tumbling of rods alters their translational and rotational trajectories and colloid-collector interactions. Our simulations showed that under favorable conditions (lacking repulsive energy barriers), rods of 0.4 - 2 mm in diameter exhibited approximately a factor of 2 - 10 greater retention compared to their equal-volume spheres. The underlying mechanisms are that for this size range, particle rotation from shape-induced fluid hydrodynamics and rotational diffusion were both important, which enabled rods to drift significantly across flow streamlines to intercept collector surfaces. Meanwhile, rotation allowed rods to migrate further downstream along flow channel for retention. The impact of particle shape on retention was more evident under high flow velocity, narrow flow channel, or flow direction parallel to gravity.

Under unfavorable conditions (energy barriers to deposition exist), colloid retention is controlled by particle transport and repulsive colloid-collector interactions, both of which are strongly influenced by particle shape. Simulations showed that shape alone could not allow rods to overcome energy barriers of over tens of kT for attachment; so colloidal retention under unfavorable conditions is attributed to particle surface heterogeneities that locally provide attractive interactions. The location of colloid surface heterogeneity strongly affected colloid-collector interactions by influencing the likelihood of heterogeneous patches facing the collector due to particle rotation. Our simulations showed that charge heterogeneity located at the end(s) of rods produced attachment with considerably smaller attractive patches relative to equal-volume spheres. For a given patch coverage, rods achieved more retention than spheres, with the extent of retention increasing with increasing aspect ratio. In contrast, when charge heterogeneities were at the middle section of rods, the patch sizes required to produce attachment were considerably larger than those for spheres and increased with increasing aspect ratio; thus, depending on colloid patch coverage, retention of rods was not necessarily greater than that of spheres. Under unfavorable conditions, the influences of colloid shape and surface properties on retention were strongly coupled. Our findings demonstrated that under idealized conditions (e.g., favorable conditions, colloid attractive patches at the ends or sides), rods exhibited distinctive (enhanced or reduced depending on colloid surface heterogeneity patterns) retention trends compared to spheres.

Simulations using colloids with randomly distributed charge patches (mimicking real colloids in the environment) showed that under high patch coverage (> 30%), retention increased with increasing aspect ratio; but under low patch coverage (< 30%), retention was insensitive to aspect ratio. This can be explained by the combined influences of particle shape and the location of attractive patches. While it was effective to increase retention with patches located on the end(s) of a rod, the likelihood of a random patch landing at the end(s) was much smaller relative to that at the middle. Also, the likelihood of a random patch at the end(s) dropped rapidly as rod aspect ratio increased. The similar retention trends for spheres and rods of different aspect ratios simulated under low random patch coverage (< 30%) may qualitatively explain the observed insensitivity in retention respecting particle aspect ratio from column breakthrough experiments using stretched polystyrene rods and spheres. Our study revealed that the stretching process (involving poly-vinyl alcohol treatment) in producing non-spherical colloids may impart particles additional surface features (e.g., hydrophobicity), which could greatly alter colloid-collector interactions and weaken the shape effect, but which have often been overlooked from many studies.

This work was among the first modeling investigations in colloidal filtration field to comprehensively explore the impact of particle shape on transport by simulating 3D rotation and translation of anisotropic colloids under the combined influences of hydrodynamic flow, external forces and Brownian motions. Our findings also provide important guidelines/references regarding colloid shape effect in other disciplines including biomedical, aerodynamic, and hydrologic fields. This award enabled us to generate 5 peer-reviewed journal articles (3 published, 2 under review), 3 conference presentations, and 1 doctoral dissertation (in preparation).
